Holy Sikh Temple. This is the 2nd Sikh temple I've seen. This place is clean enough & maintained very maintained. Sikhs are very welcoming & hospitalitable. There's a free food available,we were given kheer (as parsad). Do visit if you happen to be in Dubai.

you will get real peace here. Very well built, spacious & very well maintained Gurudwara. It's slightly offsite (in Jebel Ali ), however worth visiting many / many times. In the vicinity, there are churches also (we did not visit). Ample parking space. There is langar arrangements on all days

Holy place for prayers. Though this place little away from the main Dubai activity.Its location is excellent at a calm and peaceful surrounding. If somebody really need a peace please visit this place. Its well maintained, neat and clean and Prasadam is very much enjoyable with lunger khana

An outstanding Culture Centre across Religions. Truly a melting pot for religions, run with great dedication by the management, and a must visit for every visitor to Dubai. One of the most amazing wonders created in the Middle east and run by the Kandhari family whose selfless hard work and service will be lauded for generations.

A Touch of Heaven in Dubai. One of most beautiful, serene places you'll ever go to in Dubai. You'll want to spend at least 30 minutes in the main hall upstairs, and it's equally special at both day or night. Absolutely breath-taking in the way it welcomes and attracts people from all walks of life in Dubai. During the busiest days of the year, it can take an hour to get across SZR to get here, but if you do get a chance to visit and pay your respects then, it'll have been worth for just experiencing the sheer collective force of devotion! Once you have your experience with a little prayer, don't forget to partake of some of the blessed Prasad from the sevadars. Afterwards, you can also enjoy a free vegetarian meal at the Langar Hall downstairs, which is a wonderful experience. Definitely an experience you'll never forget!
Very peaceful. The darbar was very clean and peaceful, the wash rooms were clean, very well maintained. Felt very peaceful
Cant get better... Very peaceful and holy place to visit. Nicely built, spacious gurudwara offering langar everyday. A must visit for every Indian.
One of the most peaceful place in Dubai. This is indeed one of the most peaceful place I have ever visited in Dubai. Will keep going there again and again.

Elegant modern decor. This Sikh temple has a modern look, from outside as well as inside, elegant & different than the traditional look.Huge praying hall and langar (meal) service throughout.very much at peace inside the praying hall.
No Comparison. Once in Dubai , one must visit the Darbar Saheb. The Darshan is very nice and the Langar ( Food ) has no comparison.

Must visit. The Gurudwara is very close to the Ibn Batuta area. Very pure and extremely good vibes. Babbajis house in full grandeur. Must visit

One of the best place in Dubai. Guru Nanak Darbar Credit goes to HH Sheikh Mohammed Bin Rashid Al Makhtoum for giving permission.You need peace and serenity advisible to go during weekdays morning... Peace. Peaceful and quite . We visited the gurudwara in the evening and.it was really peaceful. We had a good visit if.the holy book and sat there for.sometime. The place is a must visit and they have buses every 10 mins to and from the metro station.

Culturally interesting. My first visit to a sikh temple. Headscarves are provided free of charge to visitors. I was glad my cousin and his family were there to show me what to do. Gurunanak Darbar. Very pious and peaceful atmosphere in and around Gurudwara. Kept very clean-as per tradition of Gurudwaras.

Beautiful. My husband and I went to this beautiful Gudwara which is easy to get to. It is very peaceful and everyone was so welcoming. You don't have to be Sikh to go and experience this lovely temple.
Sikh wedding ceremony. The venue was ideal for the actual wedding ceremony. Though it was a little far from the Marriott Marquis hotel.

Peace and serenity. Credit goes to HH Sheikh Mohammed Bin Rashid Al Makhtoum for giving permission.You need peace and serenity advisible to go during weekdays morning... Peaceful place. Like any holy places, Gurunank Darbar is a a perfect place to find peace within.Don't miss out on the Langar Prasad!

Amazing . An amazing experience- such a feeling of tranquility in Dubai... A must for all spiritual lovers!i would recommend to all faiths to visit as I am Hindu and felt most at home even though not my own faith.

Just awesome... Every indian's pride..this place of worship is one of its kind..Cant thank enough to UAE's spirit which respects every religion..Langar is available daily between 12 to 2pm..Facility for wedding ceremonies also available..
A good experience. Its a nice place for the families to visit. Near to many other main tourist attractions. Preferably try to visit during evening.
One of the most spiritually uplifting places in Dubai. Whether you want to introspect, reach out to others or just feel a spiritual rejuvenation, visit this place. Just love going to this temple.

Salute to Dubai king for this wonderful temple. This is the best gurudwara I have seen in UAE. Thanks to Dubai king generosity for allowing this place of worship . Langar ( free food ) is served on Friday and Saturday . Must for all punjabis and Indians visiting Dubai . Transport can be be of issue
Peace for the Soul. If you are looking for Peace for the Soul, this is a place where you can visit and spend some time to connect with yourself.

Peace at its best. Out of the city with no noise, get some peace at the Temple! The temple is built with a perfect mix of Sikh architecture inside a middle eastern building. Have the 'langar' there if not, dont leave without the 'chai' or 'kheer'

Go there, with some advice on how to get there. This is the third Sikh Temple I have visited, after Amritsar and Delhi, and while it is not as spectacular as those sites ti is very much worth a visit. As I have found elsewhere, the Sikhs are very welcoming, with greetings, with offers of food and a willingness to share their place of worship. Unlike Delhi and Amritsar there is no vast "tank" of water, just a small stretch out front. But inside you are guided upstairs to a large airy hall of workship, with an ornate altar at one end and thick carpets throughoutWhile I was there, three musicians were singing and playing harmonium and drums, and unlike Delhi, their amplifiation was perfect and the music incredibly hypnotic and engaging. I sat on the carpet for almost an hour soaking in the spirituality. I really enjoyed my visit.On a more practical level, the temple is a bit south of the towers of Dubai. I was staying close to the airport up north and did not want to pay for the taxi to go that far, nor did I trust I could get a taxi back from the temple. So I decided to go by the Metro, Google Maps showing about a twenty minute walk from the Energy Metro station and I know I walk faster than Google Maps suggests.The Dubai Metro is very easy to navigate, with signs and announcements in both Arabic and English. It is a long ride south to "Energy" but the Metro is clean and air conditioned and much of the ride is above ground and there are plenty of interesting towers to admire.But the arrival at "Energy" was something of a shock. The station name derives, I guess, from the refineries west of the train line. The temple is to the east, but the Google Maps route starts you on a paved road with no sidewalk (just the shoulder) and then guides you onto a dirt road that had me trudging through the sand. Mainly though, the pathway was completely deserted -- no people, no cars, no buildings, no nothing. I thought about turning back but the ability to see there was no one anywhere near made it seem safe, so I trudged. Most of the way to the temple the only other thing moving besides me was a truck that kept going back and forth spraying water on a section of the dirt road, turning it to mud. There may have been a reason for that but none I could discern.I was unsure about my return trip. Should I walk back through the open desert plain to "Energy" or try a tiwice-as-long walk, though a more built up area to "Ibn Battura" -- the next Metro stop north back to town. As I contemplated, a taxi pulled up and I had him drive to "Energy". If you are following Google Maps and you don't turn right ton the dirt road but continue to the next right you will have a longer walk but it is all paved.A car is good way to get there; there is plenty of parking. Walking from Energy to the temple took maybe ten minutes; if I had not been alone I probably would not have minded it. The visit, completely worthwhile.One more thing, Trip Advisor always asks if there is food available for purchase. The answer is no, because there is food available, but it is free.

Desert Serenity. Blessed to have got an opportunity to visit this beautiful Gurudwara in Dubai! The place is quite far from the city - but if you are going to Ibn Batuta Mall, then it's just 5 minutes from there! Location can be tricky if you don't have your own car or a taxi - as finding a taxi is next to impossible. However people visiting the temple are kind to drop you to the nearest Metro Station! The Gurudwara is huge, full of calmness and serenity. An absolute visit if you are a follower and want some peaceful time away from the craziness of Dubai city!

Place to worship. Have been staying for more than 2 years in dubai and i never knew you can get so much peace of mind at Gurunanak darbar, Was blessed on visiting the temple with family and more there are many people who help not only in the kitchen but also serve each and every people post your prayers for food. Worship and service to mankind.

Best Place.Peaceful,Amazing Langar & Seva. Away from the busy life and hustle bustle of UAE, this place is a must visit for anybody and everybody. Beautiful decor and well maintained.The scared Gurbani ,Quiet atmosphere,amazing langar and commendable seva offered by all devotees.

Dubai Gurudwara. This is newly built and not to be confused with the existing on in city area (Bur Dubai.The old one is congested and in a small area along with a temple)Excellent place to visit though far away from City centre.Close to Ibn Battuta Mall. One can take a metro and get down at Ibn Battuta station and from there a cab ( shouldn't be more thatn 15 AED from there by metre)Beautiful building and interiors and very peacefulLarge inside carpeted sitting area to meditate and listen to Gurubani/KirtansThe temple keeps inviting prominent Raagis ( devotional singers) from India off and onThe area also has a church nearbyFridays can be a rush due to church and gurudwara weekend activitiesExcellent basic food ( Langar ) served -breakfast and lunch/teaMany volunteers participate in the work Many non Indians and non Sikhs/hindus also visit to savour the community meals it serves everydayDue to Dubai rules cooked food by visiting people is not allowed to be donated or distributedRather food items in packed / raw conditions are accepted like Flour, sugar, Ghee Cannisters etcMust place to visit
True peace. Visited the gurudwara on a Friday. They have langar during lunch hours on Friday. Was amazed to see the gold takht of babaji made of 1300kg gold & with TV screens translating the sermons.
Beautiful. The temple is so well made and it feels like you are in India. The architecture is beautiful and its very peaceful even though its situated in the busy Bur dubai area.

Heaven in desert . This has been the best gurudwara I have been in foreign lands. It's so beautiful and nicely made , thanks to the king and dubai government, it's a must visit place no matter to whichever religion u belong , fridays and Saturdays u can have langer also.

Peace and faith. This is the only official Gurudwara (Sikh Temple) in middle east and kudos to Sikhs living in the Dubai who made this dream come true by the blessings of almighty Waheguru. Gurudwara is in the industrial area along with several other churches. You can take a metro till Emirate mall and then you have to hire a taxi to reach Gurudwara. Make sure that you have taxi toll free to call a taxi as it's not a crowded place where you can find a taxi easily.You can offer your prayers and eat food in langar (community kitchen). Also, you can give donations if you want ...

God's blessings in Desert. We were amazed to see the Temple in the Desert as temple is actually bit of outskirt of the city but inside it felt no different to any other temple in India or abroad. We found it very peaceful and calming to the soul and Langar at the end reminded of our local temple. It's worth a visit.

Virtually a GOLDEN TEMPLE in the Desert. My & I arrived in the afternoon in Dubai. That evening we went to Gurunanak Darbar Sahib Gurudwara. I was really awe struck at the beauty & the the construction of this great place of Worship. The only in the Arab world - I guess.Attented the Kirtan - it was so soothing and serene. The Ragees (Singers) had melodious voice. the praise for the LORd was sung from the heart.We had 'Lunger' at night. The food was well prepared, considering that there were hundreds eating. The service by the volunteers was excellent.We donated money for the 'Lunger'.It was a very satisfying experience

Peace!!. Just Being there!!! the chanting around you fills your heart..
I paid a visit on one of the occasions and it was amazing. I also ate at the lunger and they treat everyone like brothers and sisters and feed you with lot of love.

Good place. Its good that we can see a hindu / sikh temple / gurudwara in gulf.
Well maintained, disciplined.
But it is in a very congested and crowded area.

Heaven in Dubai. The most peaceful place in Dubai. Peaceful, Powerful and Positive place in Dubai. Any wish here comes true....to the best of my experience. People treat you with so much love and affection...and it is so beautiful to spend time here.

tranquil, divine and welcoming. You are greeted by a smiling security guard who guides you to the entrance. As covering your head in a Sikh Gurdwara is mandatory, there are containers with suitable head scarves for both men and women and lockers to keep your footwear in. The place is much bigger inside than you initially think. It is spotlessly clean and neat with comfortable carpeting across the room for seating the faithful. While religious scriptures are read the faithful sit and listen. A feeling of calmness and peace pervades the place as the gathered faithful sit and listen. All visitors visiting at meal times can have a vegetarian meal cooked completely in-house in the Gurdwara's own kitchen. Do make it a point to visit this Gurdwara when you are in the new Dubai area. You will be pleased you didn't miss the chance.
Excellent religious temple. I visited this temple a couple of time. Extremely peaceful place. Perfect place for you if you are a religion believer.

Amazingly peaceful & built with so much love, detail & effort. Visited this Gurdwara on a Saturaday evening 13/9, was so impressed with structure of building, the kirtan darbar session, the Palki sahib, the aura, devotion n love of the sangat. Every evening the gurdwara even sends their buses to pick sangat who work in nearby areas - and the dedication n devotion is really touching. Recommend on your visit to stay till the end of program to see how much of love & respect is given to Guru Granth Sahib after kirtan sohila to Sach Khand. If u go by taxi, hold the taxi as it's a little out of the way but about 20mts fm city.

So peaceful. Went here on a roasting hot Tuesday afternoon. It is a bit of distance from the metro station BN Battuata. This place is so peaceful as you would expect and very grand. Glad I took time out to visit

Well worth a visit. We visited the Gurdwara several times during our stay, on different days and at different times of the day.It's about a 5-10 minute drive from the Battutta Mall. Each time the taxi driver knew it's location and charged 10 AEDs. On a Friday and Saturday, there were plenty of taxis available there to bring us back or you can get the security guard to call one. Alternatively, turned right along the road, left and left again, where the hospital is (Lifeline hospital, formally, Jebel Ali hospital) and then flag one down on the main road. even as a woman alone, I was OK with this.It's very well organised, with people directing you to where shoes can be left, wash basins and the Langar Hall. There are head scarves available to cover your heads.Worshippers sit on the steps leading to the prayer hall, outside and in rows in the hall.There is a serene atmosphere to the Gurdwara, which leaves you feeling grateful to be a part of. Our children commented on it before we did. The architecture is amazing. The dome, obviously, especially when lit up is simply beautiful. It's worth walking around the building to see it from different angles. It looks polished almost from outside.Lovely, friendly people who will welcome you in and break bread with you.

A Stunning place of worship!. First views of the Gurdwara are fabulous and inspiring! One is struck by the immaculate design, when set against the desert surroundings and the deep blue sky! The grounds are immaculate. One does not need to be a follower of Sikhism to appreciate the beauty and tranquility of this lovely building. In fact, whether you have faith or not, you cannot fail to be moved by its splendour. All visitors are required to cover their heads and modest attire is expected. The management committee take great pride in what they have achieved and are more than happy to provide a guided tour if you so wish.Take a taxi to Jebel Ali and tell the driver that the Gurdwara is near the Hospital. The peace and quiet is in nice contrast to the fast pace of Dubai. This really is a must do!

Amazing!. I am so glad to see a Gurdwara in dubai :) Very well built and amazing. It will be almost impossible to get a taxi back from here, so make sure you get a taxi from your hotel and tell them to wait for you. Advise the doorman of your hotel regarding this and they will tell the taxis driver for you.

Gurudwara in Dubai. A very good initiative taken by Dubai government.. an amazing place to visit and provides place to conduct all rituals for sikh community.. you can reach here by metro and then taxi.. do try langar and parsad, if u have time..

Peaceful. Beautiful gudwara, must see for all...be respectful
And cover up and you would going to any gudwara!! we had a taxi there and asked cab driver to wait as heard would be difficult to get one back...however secruity will also order you a cab
Blessing. I Visited in 2013 stunning as the only work I can use to describe it. I am going back in 2014 and cant wait to go again. I think if you have the time go and visit as you will really enjoy.

Proud of sikhism. as a sikh you really feel proud to be place away from roots & following the same tradition which we see back india...Dont miss it @ Dubai Trip...Best way to reach here is to take metro & drop to ibn batuta metro station, from there take a cab for 10 mins drive and you have to pay minimum cab charges because it very near but still you have to pay minimum cab hiring chargesOn Friday & saturday you can have Langar also ,
Amazing!!. An amazing and serene experience visiting the most wonderful Gurdwara (Sikh Temple) in the Middle East. Well worth a visit!

Very Serene and Peaceful!. It's a great place to visit for anyone in Dubai….best way to see community service in action….doors are open to people of all faiths and religions…..very beautiful, peaceful and serene atmosphere.
Amazing. Real experience!! The kids and we all enjoyed it and got to know more about the religion. Amazing people who showed us around and we will definitely come back again :)

Glad that we visited the Gurudwara. We visited Dubai to attend a wedding and someone had recommended this Gurudwara.It turned out that the Gurudwara was a little far from where we were staying i.e, bur dubai, but worth visiting. Nevermind you beliefs,This is a place to visit!

Proud to see a gurdwara with such prestige in UAE. Family of 6 we visited the much talked about "The Dubai Gurdwara". Let me explain it is not too far out best thing take Dubai metro to IBN Buttata Mall, walk to taxi rank and ask taxi driver you want to go to gurdwara near the churches, most of them know, passed the Jebeh Ali Primary school literally 5 mins in taxi paying no more than 10 DHR. The building itself is surrounded by all other places of worship, our Gurdwara stands out for its architecture, since you arrive in it is that welcome feeling you have in any gurdwara. The office were very hospitable and gave all info about the building, they will phone for a taxi for you to return to the mall or your return. We also just missed a wedding.

nice. hard to get to, as no cab driver wants to drive you to the gudwara or even acknowledges there is one in Dubai. i asked the bus driver and he just stared at me. had i asked for a mosque, i am sure he would have had a big smile on his face and given me directions a passenger very kindly on the bus had to give me directions to the temple. people in Dubai are no doubt very ignorant to other people faith but there own. very sad and disgusting to see.
